description.narrative:
OPHI's theory of change is that rigorous development and analysis of multidimensional poverty measures will enable governments and institutions to implement better poverty reduction programmes that improve the lives of people living in poverty in ways that are meaningful to them, especially after the COVID-19 crisis.
OPHI's work seeks to translate Amartya Sens capability approach into data, focused on expanding the freedoms and capabilities of all. To this end, OPHI works to broaden poverty measurement by emphasising a multidimensional understanding of poverty, improving data on poverty by advocating for more and better data tools, building capacity by training statisticians and policymakers on multidimensional methods of measurement, and impacting policy by working with national governments and international agencies to turn measurement into more effective policy. In other words, the suggested project 'OPHI 2021-2025: Measuring and Reducing Poverty in All Its Dimensions' will continue to produce, communicate and develop capacities of statistics based on the capabilty approach.
Innovative and applicable research can provide insight on how best to reduce multidimensional poverty in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic. Communication of this research to relevant audiences, particularly national policy makers and heads of international agencies, can ensure that the measures are used to build back better in country contexts. Direct collaboration with national and international policymakers can support its use to improve poverty reduction policies. Development and implementation of context-specific national measures for policy can guide policymakers toward policies that more efficiently and effectively reduce the many deprivations experienced by people living in poverty in the country after a global pandemic.
The objective of the proposed programme is to contribute to reducing poverty in its many dimensions by working with a growing number of countries and agencies to develop and use multidimensional poverty measures, leading to the acceptance of the MPI globally and more effective and efficient poverty reduction policies, especially in the context and aftermath of the Covid-19 pandemic.

The Oxford Poverty & Human Development Initiative (OPHI) is a research and training centre within the Departement of International Development at the University of Oxford. OPHI’s strategy contributes to alleviating poverty through research, training and technical assistance with regard to the multidimensional poverty indices (MPI) of low and mid income countries. OPHI conducts capacity development to governments and international organisations on MPI, on strengthening systems for data and statistics, and on measuring poverty for informed policy-making (based on statistics).

The Oxford Poverty & Human Development Initiative (OPHI) är ett forsknings- och träningscenter under Departement of International Development på Oxfords universitet. OPHI:s vision är att bidra till att minska fattigdom genom forskning, utbildning samt tekniskt bistånd i utformandet av utvecklingsländers multidimensionella fattigdomsindex (MPI). OPHI arbetar genom kapacitetsbyggande insatser för att ge fler regeringar och internationella organisationer kunskap kring multidimensionell fattigdom, samt att stärka länders data och statistiska system för att mäta fattigdom och använda denna information (statistik) i underbyggt beslutsfattande.
